dialogues.text: LAURA DANNER, 27, neglected, oily hair, doughy skin, shut the engine. Next to her, DAVEY DANNER, 9, cradles a scratched, black toy locomotive in his lap. Laura, drowsy leans her head against the seat. Her speech is slurred.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What day is it?

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Tuesday. I told you.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: And the date.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: August eighth.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: We'll wait, Davey. We’ll wait here until it comes and then...

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Did you know the Coast Starlight goes all the way to Seattle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (praying; eyes closed) O God, you are my God, I wait for You from the dawn...

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: There’s two engineers on every passenger train. They change teams every twelve. hours.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: ..-My soul thirsts for You, my body longs for You... Pray with me, Davey.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: I already prayed.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: .--My lips will praise You for Your mercy is better than life itself. The crossing light goes from green to a flashing red.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: It’s here! She starts the car.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Wait, Mom. Don’t go! It’s coming. She presses on the gas and hurls the Lincoln forward, pas the signal, up the embankment, onto some gravel and then tracks. They bounce as the car’s tires jump the rail, the the ties and then the rail again. She stops the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lincoln sits with its front wheels over the far side the tracks. Its rear tires slightly touch the near rail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura locks the doors, takes the keys out of the ignition Wide-eyed, Davey watches as she hurls the keys out the window. She turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Time to rest now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue letters on silver cars: COAST STARLIGHT. The shiny, Majestic train is almost ready to depart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOM STARK, 44, and N.B. GARCIA, a massive man, graying ha hurry down a marble corridor - rough men who talk tough, gruffly and live hard. N.B. How you holding up, Tom? Doing alright? The long corridor is adorned with black and white picture depicting trains and passengers in the 30's and 40’s.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: My train’s running in ten minutes. N.B. No telling with that messed-up disease. My mother-in-law, God rest her soul, was only 63--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Megan's 38. N.B. Take time off. I got you covered. VINCE, 50’s, another engineer, barrels toward them holdin stack of papers: train orders. N.B. (to Vince) About time, Hoghead.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Car trouble. Sorry, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What do I care?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: (nervous) I got your train today. It’s all set with the boys upstairs. Tom studies him hard, then turns to N.B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I want to work. He pushes a door open, exiting to--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’m dealing with it my way. N.B. Listen. I'’1l give you all the streaks you can handle, but you keep running away from her, you’1l regret it forever. Tom climbs into the locomotive. MEGAN STARK, 38, pale, short blonde hair, exceedingly thin, pounds the hard soil with trowel. A palette of mixed-color impatiens sits nearby. S chooses the pink ones, entombs them in the dirt. A car pulls in the driveway. Megan smiles and rises. A sharp pain cuts through her lower back. She GASPS, fallin to her knees on the dirt.  SUSAN GARCIA, plump, in a nurse’s scrubs, exits the car holding a large copper pot. Seeing that Megan is down, sh puts the pot on the driveway and rushes toward her.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What do you think you’re doing?

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Planting flowers.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: To work in your condition...Really, it’s insane. She helps her up. They walk toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Where's Tom? I thought he was keeping an eye on you.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Sometimes I feel like he can’t stand to be around me.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable with intimate subject) My soup! She hurries down the black asphalt driveway to retrieve t copper pot. Megan, pensive, watches as Susan bends down t

dialogues.text: A_black asphalt road. It cuts a dizzyingly precipitous incline. A 50’s style building sits at the top of the hil

dialogues.text: YOUNG MEGAN, 22, adorable in a pink waitress outfit and a ponytail, and LEE, also 20's, waitress, watch YOUNG TOM, from behind the counter: Shy and stiff, he sits at one bo reading a very heavy textbook. He looks up at Megan - mee her eyes - and quickly returns to his book.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MEGAN
dialogues.text: What does he want?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Babe, he’s been coming here twice a day, every day, for two weeks. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEE (cont'd) Trust me. It’s not for the pancakes.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MEGAN
dialogues.text: You think...? Oh. She saunters to Tom’s table with a pen and pad. He looks her, smiles. She takes the book away from him.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MEGAN
dialogues.text: May I? He nods.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MEGAN
dialogues.text: (reading book title) “The Railroad: What It Is, What It Does.” Straight forward. I like that in a man. She gives the book back, looks at him expectantly. He can think of anything to say, but:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOM
dialogues.text: Coffee please.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MEGAN
dialogues.text: Haven’t you had enough for one day?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOM
dialogues.text: You’re working a double.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MEGAN
dialogues.text: On Wednesdays.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOM
dialogues.text: Right. She smiles. Tongue-tied, he opens his book and furtively watches her as she joins Lee behind the counter. She pour his coffee. The girls giggle, whispering. Megan turns - catches him staring again. She approaches with his cup, places it on the table and waits. He doesn’t say anything just grins. She sighs.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MEGAN
dialogues.text: You keep staring, but you won’t talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOM
dialogues.text: I can’t help it.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MEGAN
dialogues.text: The staring or the talking part?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MEGAN
dialogues.text: You're infuriating.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOM
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MEGAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know if I should slap you or kiss you. Repeat after me. I...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MEGAN
dialogues.text: Would like...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOM
dialogues.text: (catching on) Would like--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MEGAN
dialogues.text: To take you out sometime...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOM
dialogues.text: To take you...You’d go out with me?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MEGAN
dialogues.text: Now that you’ve asked so nicely, why not? He smiles widely. She laughs. INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - DAY It has the easy, comfortable feeling a room gets when its occupants have lived with each other for a length of time and yet the sparse furnishings make it seem transitory. Megan, holding a glass of water, lies on the bed. Susan, sitting by her, sips a bowl of her own homemade soup.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (offering soup) Sure you don’t want some? Megan shakes her head, reaches for a pill bottle and take out a capsule. She swallows it with some water. An open catalogue sits on the night stand, showing a baby grand piano. Megan puts her glass down next to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful, isn’t it? Susan glances at the catalogue.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The piano?

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: I ordered it.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: I’‘m going to learn how to play. I've always wanted to learn.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Oh, Megan. Megan! You have to rest. Take it easy.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: “Do not go gentle into that good night...Rage, rage, rage against the dying of the light.”

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Is that what you’re doing? Raging?

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: It’s a Dylan Thomas poem. Did I ever tell you I was an English major? The phone rings on the night stand. Megan ignores it. It rings again, making Susan anxious.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Should I get it? She puts the soup down and hurries to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (into phone) Stark residence...No, it’s not, may I say who’s calling...Oh...Is he alright?...Yes...Yes...thank you. Shaken, she puts down the phone. Megan, puzzled, studies

dialogues.text: (into radio) This is the Coast Starlight, and we are setting up and running...Wanda, your favorite train is leaving...

dialogues.speaker: TOM

dialogues.text: Megan...

dialogues.text: Yes, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOM
dialogues.text: How do you feel about trains now?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MEGAN
dialogues.text: I love them...  11.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOM

dialogues.text: You will be gentle with him... I think he suffers from PTSD. (off Judy’s clueless look) Post Traumatic Stress Disorder.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: It's just that his mother--

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Stop. You already told me. Separate yourself from your job, Renee. They‘re not your children.

dialogues.speaker: VENTURA CHILDREN

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Romeo... He checks his watch, removes the headset and gets on the intercom. PASSENGERS settle in reclining seats.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Welcome to the Coast Starlight. We're happy to have you on board.

dialogues.text: There's going to be a hearing. I have to be here to find out when.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Good. An official excuse.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It's not an excuse. If I’m absent at the hearing, I’ll lose my job.

dialogues.text: You’re like sand, Tom. The harder I try to hold you, the quicker you slip through my fingers. She exits to--

dialogues.text: I can’t answer that.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: I won't hold you to it. Give me your best guess.

dialogues.speaker: DR. OFFENBERGER
dialogues.text: You sure you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Please, Doctor. He meets her eyes.

dialogues.text: Hello Train Riders...  16.

dialogues.text: This is a good place, you'll see.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Megan? I’m Sheila, it’s a pleasure to meet you. Peace and love.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Hi, Tom. (to Megan) Tom thinks we can help you. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEILA (cont'd) He was very convincing on the phone. Did you browse through our brochure?

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Briefly.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: We're a center for alternative approaches to treat or ameliorate disease. We offer applied kinesiology, cupping, and even electromagnetic therapy.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Can you cure me?

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: We're one of the best centers in the country.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: You didn’t answer my question.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Tom tells us you’re a nurse. As a professional from the medical field, you know there are no guarantees. However, we can try to rejuvenate your system, teach you a number of relaxation techniques.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: I don’t want to relax. I want to live.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: For Christ's sake Megan, will you just listen to her?

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: That's alright, Tom. Of course you want to live, Megan, but—-

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: And I intend to spend the rest of my life doing exactly what I want. Electromagnetic therapy is not on my list. She rises and leaves. Tom, upset, looks at Sheila.  18.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: (smiling patiently) Give her time. She‘ll come around.
